comments.commentBody: We will all stand before God
I'm not Catholic, but he's my Pope.
Mine too! I like to get Poped up...makes me feel more human, and a little braver as well.
Actually, gift cards are regularly sold at pawn shops for cash (10 cents on the dollar), and a hit of heroin is just $5.
Thank you, Pope Francis. I came to this conclusion some time ago. I especially like to give bottles of water during the brutal summer heat in Texas.
Thanks for this lovely piece.
It has worked for me.

The lingering question: Why all the Trump praise for Putin?
Sure seems like Donald had ulterior motives for his
obsession, always volunteering comment.
A better solution would be birth control.
Birth control is good, excellent, but not necessarily better than compassion, and one on one encounters.

Better your mother had used it than produced someone who would make such an unfeeling remark.

I'm a secular humanist, but do believe in principles like The Golden Rule and the statement that "There but for the grace of God go I."

A very insensitive response.  I would prefer associating with a homeless person than someone who is as uncompassionate as you.  Remember there but for the Grace of God go I.  I could go on but must remain Christian during this Lenten season.

The Guardian has reported that Sessions, while a prosecutor in Alabama unfairly prosecuted Democratic officials and activists, ruining her reputations, and sending some innocents to prison. Is it surprising that this attack dog would lie? The whole Trump administration says one thing one day and unsays it the next. then it spreads falsehoods. that it cannot be trusted to tell the truth. In the meantime, Republican senators seem cool with that. As a whole, Republican senators cannot be counted on to speak truth about this debacle.

Governor Walker claims this is not about ideology. Instead it is about the choice Americans made in November. Unfortunately, Gov. Walker, a majority of Americans could not agree on a candidate. The candidate that received the most votes in the general election is not president. But regardless of who won or even received a majority of the popular vote, with an election that is even close, and with a complete absence of coherence in the campaign of the winner, how can we have any idea what the voters were actually voting for? This is no more than justification after the fact for a proposal based on ideology and little more. The people do not want schools that are only funded by the local community. I do not want children in poor states, within poor districts to receive a shoddy education in a shoddy building. Our government is huge in large part because we are by far the largest democracy in the world in economic terms. We are an enormous, complicated country, of course we have an enormous government.
So if you live in a rich state, you are lucky but if you are not, tough luck!  This is not the solution chosen by Canada or many European countries.  As usual The U.S. shows how backward it is.

"Flight tests of interceptors based in Alaska and California had an overall failure rate of 56 percent, under near-perfect conditions. Privately, many experts warned the system would fare worse in real combat."

In naval history, actual hit rates in war were less than a third of even the most realistic testing of peacetime. There are far worse examples, such as infantry marksmanship. There are no examples of wartime performance matching peacetime tests, even tests done under "realistic" conditions.

That same principle must apply to cyberwar efforts, since it applies to everything else ever known.

The answers are layering and overkill.

A good offensive is better than a good defensive, because partial success works out better on the offensive.

However, there can be no thought of "surgical strikes;" That has never happened, a false claim repeatedly disappointed.

Also, when offensive means starting a fight, one must remember they are much easier to start than to finish. Along the way, the other side gets in some painful shots. After Pearl Harbor, Japan wanted to stop the Pacific War with negotiations over how much of its initial gains it would keep, and look how that worked out. Germany took most of Europe and much of Russia, and look how that turned out. A good start is very far from a good end.
Let's have Trump release his taxes like every other president and we'll call it even.  Or, will the light of day reveal something...untoward?

Scott Walker is a stealth misanthrope because he looks like a regular guy but is anything but.  He hates anyone who does not share his beliefs.  He has tried to destroy unions, is against teachers earning a living wage, could care less about the vulnerable, wants to cut health care and otherwise deprive anyone but his own kind.  Never mind anyone in need.  Now he wants to curtail our constitutional right to assembly because many of us do not agree with him and see him espousing extreme un-American ideals.  Greedy, self aggrandizing and a power grabber, he is a real threat to this country

Sorry to contradict, but Scott Walker did not campaign on the severe restrictions to public unions he and the Wisconsin GOP enacted in Act 10--indeed, in private he described release of Act 10 as "dropping the bomb".  Nor did he campaign on imposing austerity on our public schools, which now have trouble attracting teachers; nor on allowing the state's roads and bridges to fall into disrepair. He did campaign on a pledge to not borrow money, which he has subsequently embraced. During the protests, he was nowhere to be found--much like Wisconsin's Republican congressional delegation these days. He has been governor to his base, and to his wealthy out-of-state backers, not to the state's citizens as a whole.  And taking care of the poor? Please, give me a break! It's been a war on the poor. Did any of this help Wisconsin's economy? Wisconsin's economic performance has been mediocre at best.  Our neighbor Minnesota, which has taken the opposite past, is booming, while incomes in Wisconsin have stagnated. Walker's cuts to the University of Wisconsin and attacks on tenure have driven away many of the most talented professors, undermining what is arguable one the strongest drivers of innovation and job growth.

I hope Governor Walker didn't strain something patting himself on the back in this article.  Some big companies like Caterpillar and Oscar Mayer are leaving his state, and most of the jobs Wisconsin's economy has created are lower level, service industry jobs.  We need look no further than nearby Brownbakistan - er, Kansas - to see what a disaster the extreme implementation of Walker's low-tax, low-regulation strategy can bring down on a state's citizens.  Walker is nothing but an idealogue, and his utterly weak attempt to place himself on the national stage by running for president strongly suggests not everyone is buying what he is selling.

I find it luridly fascinating that a man who has been dodging voters in Wisconsin from his entire term in office would close a ridiculous and shallow call to arms by saying "face the voters- and get to work". People like him are convinced erroneously of their own moral AND fiscal superiority. Instead of writing this insane, stupid tripe he should shut up and get to work himself.

By standing strong Walker means ignore the masses of people who oppose his agenda, and the republican agenda as a whole.

I think Obama should have prosecuted the banksters, the right wing politicians who profited from the collapse in 2007, and the war crimes by Rumsfeld, Cheney, and Bush. And I think the next Democratic President knows this. The republicans have ignored the laws of this country for so long they think they're immune.

Bring it on, Scott. Your days are numbered. The more you protest the protesters, the more likely your gonna see jail time.
Good point, Sara G.  I would like to get paid for what I was going to do for free.  Who do I send my invoice to?

So the message is to ignore protesters because doggone it, they're wrong. It's breathtaking how on the one hand constituents' opinions matter when you and your party have so gerrymandered every district in the country, and done your utmost to deny brown and elderly people the basic right to vote that Republicans get illegitimately elected. And yet when people show up and protest, their opinions don't matter and they should just be ignored. Vox populi, (but only if they're voting Republican). Yet another obvious hypocrisy from yet another Republican. Maybe one day a Republican will make an argument that's at least internally consistent.

Still waiting for all those tax cuts for rich guys to trickle down to the restuvus, by the way.

Gov. Divide and Conquer's idea of a balanced budget is a projected $693 million deficit by 2019 and a $1 billion road deficit. By saving a couple hundred property tax dollars a year, we now have underfunded, deteriorating schools and roads while we pay more for everything from park stickers to license plates with anemic economic and wage growth to show for it.

He espouses states rights but undermines municipal authority through state imposed restrictions on local referendums, usually trying to bridge school funding deficits imposed by his cabal.

A study of claims data from UnitedHealth Care, Humana and Aetna puts the cost of Wisconsin healthcare at 81% above the national average while he pushes to shutter Planned Parenthood.

We're consistently at the bottom in business start ups and entrepreneurship with more people leaving the state than moving in and he has yet to deliver the 250,000 new jobs he promised in 2010.

With all the challenges Wisconsin faces, his priority is to drug test SNAP recipients and appeal an unconstitutional gerrymandering federal court decision. His 'high road' leads straight to his patrons at Koch Industries and The Bradley Foundation. If you believe his malarkey, he'll sell you a mine for $700,000 in dark money campaign contributions.

Scott Walker is, among many other things, on the wrong side of history, among the many other things he's on the wrong side of.

But he's a dyed in the wool republican, whatever that is these Trumpian days, and like all sucking animals, won't be dislodged without a fight.

Yawn.

I love how all these states rights supporters are the first to call the white house when a natural disaster occurs in their states. Scott brown, Nikki Haley, Bobby Jindial, the first call they made was to the federal government crying "we need help send us help". 500,000 Americans died on our soil to preserve this union and we never have to deal with Texas trying to seize Oklahoma for their oil fields. Our animosity gets played out on Saturday on a football field and then we go out together for a beer. Call "State's Rights" what it really is racism and bigotry.

The in-your-face hypocrisy of Trump and congressional Republicans is infuriating. Trump's hate-mongering, fear-mongering birther campaign, a calculated, filthy lie about Barack Obama, is the witch hunt that has inflicted the greatest damage in polarizing Americans. Almost as destructive was the Republicans' foamy-mouthed frenzy over Hillary Clinton's role in Benghazi.

Ironically Trump, who lives in a make-believe reality and deep denial of real facts, doesn't seem to understand that "witch hunt" implies the search for a fantasy being. Trump's lies and cheating are no fantasy as the hunt will surely reveal, if only congressional Republicans appoint a special prosecutor to get it done.
When they get to the bottom of this scandal, I wouldn't be surprised if they uncover Donald Trump's Russian Birth Certificate.
The protesters are your employers. Shut up and listen.
